title: Thomas Cook strengthens China ties with Club Med partnership

Tue, Jul 21, 2015, 16:45 BST - UK Markets closed Thomas Cook strengthens China ties with Club Med partnership By Ben Martin | Telegraph – 20 minutes ago 1.855 -0.035 
The British tour operator has deepened its relationship with Chinese conglomerate Fosun through a tie-up with the French resorts business 
Thomas Cook (Xetra: A0MR3W - news ) has deepened its ties with Chinese conglomerate Fosun by striking a new partnership with Club Med, the French resorts business that the Shanghai-based giant bought earlier this year. 
The FTSE 250 company is already the biggest third-party distributor of Club Med holidays in France and British customers can currently book breaks at the resorts through the tour group’s branches. 
However, the latest, three-year strategic partnership seeks to broaden the relationship, and the pair hope that by forging closer ties, annual sales of Club Med products through Thomas Cook will surge by 60pc to €100m by 2018. 
The two companies will embark on joint initiatives and will consider shared short and long-haul flights. So-called “Club Med corners” will be set up in Thomas Cook travel agencies and there will also be a section of the tour operator’s website that is dedicated to the French resorts business. 
Club Med hopes that by tapping into Thomas Cook’s European sales network it will gain more customers in countries including the UK, Germany, Russia, Poland and the Czech Republic. 
The partnership also brings Thomas Cook even closer to Fosun, which bought Club Med for €939m in February and became one of the biggest shareholders in the British company the following month. 
Thomas Cook is forging close relationships in China 
Strengthening the relationship with Club Med is one of three initiatives that Thomas Cook is pursuing with the Chinese giant, which was co-founded by Guo Guangchang, an entrepreneur known as the Warren Buffett of the East . They are also setting up a €500m investment fund to buy hotels that would be managed by the FTSE 250 business, and last month established a joint venture in China to take advantage of the country’s fast-growing and lucrative market for domestic and international travel. 
Investors are expecting a further update on the Fosun partnership when Thomas Cook posts third-quarter numbers next Thursday. The tour operator is also likely to estimate the size of the hit it has taken from the deadly terrorist attack in Tunisia last month, which resulted in travel companies scrapping trips to the country.
